channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hungary’s Viktor Orban and European Far-Right Leaders Welcome Trump’s Return
item.description: Viktor Orban of Hungary and other right-wing European politicians hail the return of a U.S. president who shares their tough views on issues like immigration.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary gambled heavily and publicly on a Trump victory.

item.title: How My War Came Home
item.description: A reporter thought of his city in the west of Ukraine as a haven from Russian bombs — until a strike hit his street.
item.dc:creator: Yurii Shyvala
item.media:description: Ukrainians gathered at the site of a Russian strike on a residential area of Lviv, in western Ukraine, in September. The yellow apartment building in the background is where the reporter and his family live.

item.title: Antisemitic Attacks Prompt Emergency Flights for Israeli Soccer Fans
item.description: Dutch and Israeli officials said the fans had been attacked in Amsterdam after tensions flared around an Israeli team’s visit.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Christopher F. Schuetze, Jin Yu Young and Claire Moses

item.title: Argentina Drove Down Teen Pregnancy. Then Came Javier Milei.
item.description: Argentina has been known as one of Latin America’s most socially progressive countries. But President Javier Milei’s austerity measures have cut programs aimed at helping women.
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Natalie Alcoba and Anita Pouchard Serra
item.media:description: Feminist-themed paintings in the small town of Oran, Province of Salta, Argentina.

item.title: Gazan Rescue Service Has Stopped Operating in the North
item.description: Residents had to dig through rubble in search of their neighbors after the main emergency service in Gaza said it had stopped operations in the north because it had come under Israeli attacks.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: Palestinians inspected the damage outside a building that was struck during an Israeli bombardment in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Hits Ukraine with Drones, Missiles Overnight
item.description: Millions trek to shelters nightly or take their chances at home as unceasing missile and drone attacks drag on. Some Ukrainians are looking — with hope or sarcasm — to Trump for respite.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: People clear debris outside a school damaged by a Russian strike in Odesa, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Party Whose Leader Is Known for Antisemitism to Join Lithuanian Government
item.description: A new coalition includes a party led by a politician notorious for antisemitic remarks, another blow to the longstanding refusal by Europe’s mainstream parties to join with those seen as extremist.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Remigijus Zemaitaitis, leader of a new party, gave up his seat in Parliament this year to avoid impeachment over antisemitic remarks.

item.title: Ireland to Hold Snap General Election: What to Know
item.description: The Republic of Ireland will hold a general election on Nov. 29, after Prime Minister Simon Harris dissolved parliament on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Simon Harris, the prime minister of Ireland, in Washington last month.

item.title: Interpol Tightens Oversight After Autocrats Target Its Databases
item.description: The changes are intended to stop governments from using the world’s largest police organization to harass and monitor political dissidents.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Florentina Olareanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: The challenge of policing abuses of Interpol’s systems will fall to the organization’s new secretary general, Valdecy Urquiza of Brazil.

item.title: What the Collapse of Germany’s Ruling Coalition Means
item.description: After decades of relative stability, the country has entered a new era of political fragmentation and will hold new elections at a precarious time.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany fired his finance minister, who leads one of the three parties in the governing coalition.

item.title: Australia Moves to Ban Young Teens From Social Media
item.description: The proposed legislation would put the country at the forefront of regulating social media access for children.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Australia has proposed a ban on teenagers from social media.

item.title: Gaza’s Cease-Fire Talks Will Probably Wait Until After Trump’s Inauguration
item.description: Any major progress on a cease-fire will probably have to wait until after January’s inauguration, analysts said. Gazans said they were divided about whether Mr. Trump would do much to stop the war.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Bilal Shbair and Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York after the election. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has welcomed Donald J. Trump’s win, but how Mr. Trump might rearrange the regional chessboard is unclear.

item.title: China Braces for a New Era of U.S. Rivalry With Trump’s Return
item.description: Beijing is expecting more volatility and competition with the United States, though a lackluster economy may limit China’s options for pushing back.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: A passer-by in Beijing on Wednesday watching a state news broadcast of Donald J. Trump declaring victory in the U.S. presidential election.

item.title: Putin Lavishes Praise on Trump, Saying Russia Is ‘Open’ to Restored Ties
item.description: Russians close to the Kremlin voiced optimism that Donald J. Trump could help end the war in Ukraine on Russia’s terms. Vladimir V. Putin said Mr. Trump’s remarks on ending the war “deserve attention.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Presidents Donald J. Trump and Vladimir V. Putin in Helsinki in 2018.

item.title: Who Is Viktor Orban, Hungary’s Authoritarian Leader and Friend of Trump?
item.description: The long-serving prime minister, a champion of ‘illiberal democracy,’ has been politically isolated in much of Europe. But he has found common ground with the former and soon-to-be new U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary and Donald J. Trump, then president, at the White House in 2019.

item.title: What to Know About the Attacks on Israeli Soccer Fans in Amsterdam
item.description: Dutch and Israeli officials described the clashes after a soccer match as antisemitic.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Police officers formed a security cordon around a bus after the soccer match in Amsterdam early Friday.

item.title: America’s Wobbly Democracy
item.description: Lessons from a London bridge.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: The Millennium Bridge in London.

item.title: Elon Musk Joined Trump’s Call With Zelensky
item.description: Elon Musk was with Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago when the president-elect spoke with Ukraine’s leader. It is not clear if they discussed any change in U.S. policy toward Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Elon Musk provided the Trump campaign with financial and logistical support.

item.title: Playing Out a Dream, a Long, Long Way From Home
item.description: An academy of a team in England’s lower leagues offers Americans at the end of their collegiate eligibility a chance to continue their soccer careers.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Are England’s lower leagues the new study abroad?

item.title: Notre-Dame’s Bells Ring Together for First Time Since Fire
item.description: The sound of Notre-Dame’s bells pealed throughout Paris for the first time since 2019 — a symbol of rebirth as it prepares to reopen next month.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Three new bells, donated by the organizing committee of the Paris Olympics, in front of the Notre-Dame Cathedral on Thursday.

item.title: With Trump Tariffs Looming, Businesses Try to ‘Run From a Moving Target’
item.description: Companies are filling their warehouses or looking into moving factories as they weigh President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threats to impose tariffs on foreign goods.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Companies are reckoning with President-elect Donald J. Trump’s promises to remake international trade by raising the tariffs the United States puts on foreign products.

item.title: India Scraps Import Ban on Salman Rushdie’s ‘Satanic Verses’
item.description: In 1988, India ruled that Salman Rushdie’s novel “The Satanic Verses” could not be imported. This week, the ban was lifted because officials could not find the original order.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Pragati K.B.
item.media:description: Salman Rushdie in Frankfurt, Germany, last year.

item.title: Will Musk Influence Trump on Climate Change and Electric Vehicles?
item.description: The Tesla billionaire is a key figure in the president-elect’s orbit. One question is whether his views on climate and clean energy will have any sway.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: Elon Musk is expected to have a direct line to the White House in the coming months.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Donald Trump proposed an assortment of loosely defined tax cuts during his campaign, but lawmakers and his advisers are undecided about how much they will lower taxes again.

item.title: Prince William: Past Year Hardest of Life, After Kate and Charles’ Cancer Diagnoses
item.description: While in South Africa for the Earthshot Prize, the prince told reporters that the cancer diagnoses of his wife, Catherine, and his father, King Charles, had been “brutal.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince William was greeted by crowds in South Africa during a visit to Kalk Bay Harbour in Cape Town on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Biden promises a peaceful transition
item.description: Plus, the readers turning to “healing fiction.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden yesterday at the White House.

item.title: European Leaders Meet Amid Trump Victory and Global Uncertainty
item.description: Leaders from across Europe and beyond gathered to discuss the war in Ukraine, immigration and plans for a second Trump presidency.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A session at the European Political Community in Budapest on Thursday. The meeting comes on the heels of recent political events in the United States and Germany.

item.title: After a 2,000-Mile Trip, a Penguin Finds Itself on an Australian Beach
item.description: “This is the furthest north I’ve heard of an emperor penguin,” an expert said.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: From ice to sand: The penguin who found its way Down Under.

item.title: For Rent: 4-Bedroom London House. The Owner? Prime Minister Keir Starmer
item.description: Keir Starmer has rented out his home in north London since moving to Downing Street, according to newly published official records.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Keir Starmer and his wife, Victoria Starmer, outside their north London home in 2020.

item.title: What to Know About COP29 and How the U.S. Election Affects Climate Talks
item.description: Diplomats and leaders from around the world are gathering for annual climate negotiations. Here’s what they’re all about and what Donald Trump’s victory means for the meeting.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Diplomats and heads of state from nearly 200 countries are gathering in Azerbaijan to update their plans to address climate change.

item.title: Why the Australian Ambassador Deleted Tweets Critical of Trump
item.description: The envoy, Kevin Rudd, said that he had removed the posts “out of respect for the office of the president.” But it was a sign of broader anxiety over Donald J. Trump’s return to power.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, center right, has defended the appointment of Kevin Rudd, center left, as envoy to the United States. They toured the U.S. Capitol last year.

item.title: Dozens Killed as Israeli Strikes Pound Lebanon, Health Ministry Says
item.description: The deadliest strikes hit the Bekaa Valley, in and around the historic city of Baalbek, overnight.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ephrat Livni

item.title: World Needs Much More Aid to Adapt to Climate Shocks, U.N. Says
item.description: A new report, urging rich nations to give more climate aid to poorer ones, comes as Donald Trump’s election throws global climate talks into disarray.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Carrying supplies through a flooded area of Feni, Bangladesh, in August.

item.title: Canada Could Use a New Approach to Dealing With Trump This Time
item.description: While Canadian lawmakers are publicly sanguine about the incoming U.S. administration, several experts say that Canada faces significant challenges.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, shown in 2019, spoke by phone on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Will Test European Solidarity on NATO, Ukraine and Trade
item.description: Another Trump term could spur Europe’s efforts to stand on its own, but it is far from clear its leaders will seize the moment this time.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: European officials at the Defense Ministers’ Council at NATO Headquarters in Brussels last month.

item.title: Russia Keeps Hitting Ukrainian Cities With Waves of Drones
item.description: Moscow has been using decoy drones with no warheads to overwhelm defenses, and surveillance drones and strike drones to gather intelligence, Ukrainian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An apartment building in Kyiv, Ukraine, was damaged by debris last week. Attacks in the city by explosive-laden drones have become a near-nightly occurrence.

item.title: Gulf States See Trump as Ally They Can Do Business With
item.description: The Gulf region is looking to the next U.S. administration for help in ending the Mideast war and firm cooperation on security and economic interests.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.media:description: During his first term as President, Donald J. Trump made his first overseas trip to Saudi Arabia, signaling the importance he placed on the relationship.

item.title: Japan's Prime Minister Skillfully Managed Trump
item.description: Shinzo Abe, then the prime minister of Japan, succeeded in making friends with Mr. Trump through golf, entertainment and appealing to his vanity.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe, then the prime minister of Japan, with Donald J. Trump at the White House in 2018.

item.title: Typhoon Yinxing Hits Philippines as a Powerful Storm
item.description: The tropical cyclone, which hit the island of Luzon, prompted evacuation orders for more than 160,000 residents. Early Friday, officials warned that “life-threatening conditions persist.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Isabella Kwai and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Villagers wade in floodwater in the town of Aparri in the Philippines on Friday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: What another Trump presidency means for America and the world.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump on election night in West Palm Beach, Florida.

item.title: Air Pollution in Pakistan’s Largest Province Leaves Hundreds Hospitalized
item.description: The authorities in Lahore, home to 13 million people and the country’s second-biggest city, have told half the work force to stay home.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Heavy smog in Lahore, Pakistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: 2024 Temperatures Are on Track for a Record High, Researchers Find
item.description: The new report also says that global warming has hit a threshold, at least temporarily, that countries had pledged to avoid.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The dry bed of the Madeira River, a tributary of the Amazon, in northwestern Brazil in September.

item.title: Special Edition: What a Trump Victory Means
item.description: Plus, what to expect from his foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Donald Trump on election night in West Palm Beach, Florida.

item.title: Germany’s Coalition Collapses, Leaving the Government Teetering
item.description: After months of disputes, Chancellor Olaf Scholz ousted one of his governing partners, adding to the challenges for Europe since Donald Trump’s election.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Olaf Scholz, head of Germany’s three-party center-left government.

item.title: Geoff Capes, World’s Strongest Man, Is Dead at 75
item.description: He pulled dump trucks, flipped cars and tossed five-pound bricks as if they were Kleenex boxes. Tending to parakeets brought out his gentler side.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:description: Geoff Capes in 1983, when he established a world record in truck pulling by hauling a Mercedes-Benz tractor-trailer to the finish line in 54.3 seconds.

item.title: U.S. Election Sends Alarming Message for Global Climate Efforts
item.description: The Trump victory sets back the world’s attempt to rein in dangerous levels of warming and potentially isolates the United States in the global energy transition.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A TV in a Hong Kong restaurant showed U.S. election returns Wednesday.

item.title: Trump’s Win Ends a Post-World War II Era of U.S. Leadership
item.description: For the past four years, President Biden has argued that the first Trump term was a blip in American history. The election has proved that President-elect Donald J. Trump was no aberration.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden speaking at a news conference during the NATO Summit in Washington in July. Mr. Biden is one in a long line of presidents who have largely viewed America’s allies as a force multiplier.

item.title: Who Is Gideon Saar, Israel’s New Foreign Minister?
item.description: Over the years, he has been both a supporter and foe of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Gideon Saar, Israel’s newest foreign minister.

item.title: What’s at Stake for Mexico in a Second Trump Presidency?
item.description: Tariffs, border crossings, mass deportations of migrants and military strikes on cartels: Mexico is in the firing line of the president-elect.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump talking about border security and migrant crime during a campaign stop in Austin, last month.

item.title: What Were Trump’s Policies on Israel In His First Term as President?
item.description: Donald Trump staunchly supported Israel during his first term as president, even when that meant reversing decades of American policy.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: A billboard congratulating Donald J. Trump in Tel Aviv on Wednesday.

item.title: Israeli Officials Embrace Trump Victory, Despite His Unpredictability
item.description: There is a belief in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing Israeli government that a Trump administration will allow it to end its wars on favorable terms.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Supporters of Donald J. Trump gathering at a bar in Jerusalem to watch the reporting of U.S. election results on Wednesday.

item.title: For Ukraine, Trump Victory Signals a Shift. To What, Is Unclear.
item.description: As U.S. president, Donald J. Trump will inherit a role as Ukraine’s chief benefactor. But he has been skeptical about continuing aid to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Siversk, eastern Ukraine. The city has been under heavy shelling from Russian-occupied territory.

item.title: World Reacts to Donald Trump’s Win in U.S. Presidential Election
item.description: Donald J. Trump has said he would transform America’s relationship with allies and adversaries. He has pledged to end the war in Ukraine in 24 hours, increase tariffs and deport millions.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Catherine Porter and Neil MacFarquhar
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Watching news of the U.S. presidential election in Tokyo, on Wednesday.

item.title: By Firing Gallant, Netanyahu Removes One Threat but Risks Another
item.description: Yoav Gallant, the departing defense minister, opposed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on key policies. His dismissal has stirred public discontent.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant saluting as a sign of respect to Israel’s security forces at the end of a news conference in Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: Japan’s Mount Fuji Gets Snow After Breaking Snowless Record
item.description: Mount Fuji, the country’s tallest summit, is revered for its snowy peak. A snowfall reported on Wednesday ended its longest snowless period in 130 years.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: A sign with a photo of Mount Fuji, with the snowless mountain in the distance, last week.

item.title: Mexico’s Top Court Dismisses Proposal to Invalidate Judicial Overhaul
item.description: The move spares the country’s new president from having to choose between recognizing a court decision to strike down the overhaul or aligning with her party’s leaders and ignoring it.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
item.media:description: People holding photographs of the Supreme Court justices during a protest against a judicial reform law in Mexico City, on Tuesday.

item.title: Who Is Yoav Gallant?
item.description: The Israeli defense minister was fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel after the two clashed over the course of Israel’s war in the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant at Israel’s Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv on Tuesday, after being fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
